replies.author: @ossapinhosfazemhumah
replies.text:
to be very clear. 
Vonnegut has the 135000 figure in his book because thats the information he had at the time. his portrail of the bombing at no point tries to paint the germas as innocent victims. he was there as a POW during the bombing, as were many English and American soldiers who did not survive it. He and the few survivors of the POW camp in the slaughter house walked out to see only devastation and in the book that is portrayed in the most bleak and objective way. the book is half science fiction, dealing with a character who experiences time in a non-linear manner. but the period marked by war in the characters life is the first hand account of the author himself. and it paints noone as heroes. you dont finish slaughterhouse 5 with the sense that the Dresden bombing was an uncharacteristic act of villainy, you leave the book with a sense of the horror inherent to war itself. Vonneguts main thing in the writing of this book was to show how young and unprepared the american soldiers were. his firsthand account in war was brief and filled with needless suffering. there is no trying to recontextulize the dresden bombing in the book. just a bleak chapter in a mans life.

replies.text: Kurt Vonngut on Dresden : ‚ÄúNear as anybody knows, it was the largest massacre in human history. I mean Auschwitz was a slow killing process. In order to qualify as a massacre there has to be the killing of a whole lot of people in a very short time.‚Äù

replies.author: @jehaert
replies.text:
@ossapinhosfazemhumah just pasting my other comment: Vonnegut is warping historic facts and tells a very disturbing narrative: mainly nothing matters, because verything already happened and the future is settled. (the sci-fi side story and what the aliens tell him)
also with his reappearing phrase "so it goes" he relativises every single death in the book to be the same, as they don't matter ultimately, plus he uses it for human and animals deaths alike. even more disturbing. also the character and apparently everyone else in the book are being led by external forces, which effectively exculpating everyone involved - which ironically makes the bombing of Dresden meaningless, but what doI know. 
I had a presentation on the book in my literature class and one of Vonnegut's friends, my professor's menthor from the U.S., incidently, was there and was quite interested in these views. He said he was sure Vonnegut wouldn't agree with this interpretation, though. And I'm almost certain the book is more about how it feels to the main character, rather than being a solid case against trying to wrap your head around history and understanding what happened - an enlightened and critical view. 
Anyway, I didn't feel comfortable reading this especially knowing that to him Auschwitz wasn't as bad the Dresden bombing, simply because Auschwitz was slower and not one big massacre in which a lot of people died in a short time. (Slaughterhouse Five - Kurt Vonnegut (Bloom's Modern Critical Interpretations p. 84, if my paper can still be trusted), thereby completely neglecting the quality of the matter or the historical context.

Don't get me wrong even the Royal Air Forcer (or the American Air Force I'm not sure tbh) completed a report which effectively made clear that the "Moral Bombing" had no effect and that in fact the allies had underestimated certain parts of the german industrial centers, such as big transformer stations and the vastness of the german electrical network, thus bombing the wrong targets. 
Nevertheless the way people deal with this book is objectionable.

replies.author: @jimbajim
replies.text:
@jehaert I think that a more nuanced way to read the whole determinism thing isn't really to erase agency (though of course it certainly does in a way). It's not that the main character SHOUDLNT do anything, it's that he CAN'T. Lack of agency is only really for him, because he's the only one who time travels. Those fighting go on because they think that their country is threatened or that innocents will be killed, but only our "hero" can see that even passion enough to kill for is ultimately killing. It's not that we shouldnt ever use violence, it's that it really, really, really sucks for everybody whenever it's used, deserved or not. It always sucks, even for those who are right (though have no way of knowing, because they're not time-travellers). 
As to Auschwitz, I see nothing that is exculpatory of Nazi genocide. His saying that Auschwitz "didn't count" as a massacre because it doesn't fit into our silly categorization of "massacre". He heard Dresden was the "biggest slaughter" and then says "I guess the fuckin genocide didn't count then..!?!?!"

replies.author: @tawdryhepburn4686
replies.text:
@jehaert you have a _fascinating_ take on Slaughterhouse Five. I don‚Äôt think I have ever disagreed more wholly with an interpretation of a book. He is not minimizing death by offering the same epitaph to humans and animals alike; he is urging the reader to see that _life is life!_ the phrase ‚ÄúSo it goes‚Äù is bitterly ironic. It‚Äôs a scream into the blackness of oblivion, saying that in spite of the incalculable suffering, life is precious. You‚Äôre not supposed to agree ‚ÄúSo it goes.‚Äù It‚Äôs supposed to alert you to the idea that beneath the banality, what has happened - what _is_ happening - is horrible and tragic. 

Also, the whole thing is as potent a metaphor for POST TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER as I have ever encountered. (And I have firsthand experience with the affliction).  

I would recommend that you try reading MotherNight, Slaughterhouse Five, and Breakfast of Champions to better grok Vonnegut‚Äôs intended message. All three novels are basically identical thematically, and serve as refinements on the core theme and moral philosophy. 

All of that said, I must agree with you assessment of Vonnegut‚Äôs quote on Dresden vs Auschwitz. What a horrible, pointless thing to say. I hope there was some larger context, because it physically pains me to read these words.

replies.author: @juliadonati8245
replies.text: @tawdryhepburn4686 Thanks for making this comment. Your explanation of how ‚Äúso it goes‚Äù functions as a phrase really evoked the phrase‚Äôs intended meaning. Also, it‚Äôs so rare to see the word grok in the wild so it‚Äôs a treat when it happens.

replies.author: @juliadonati8245
replies.text:
@jehaert I‚Äôm going to defend determinism because I have no choice. (See what I did there?)  ;)

My real reason is that the B theory of time where all potentialities are equally real is vindicated by relativity and I believe that determinism is true, yet the awful consequences of determinism as a worldview don‚Äôt affect me. 

Just because a person‚Äôs actions were determined before they occurred, doesn‚Äôt mean they necessarily have the same moral weight. So many steps in the chain could have been altered and their actions could been prevented if something in their environment caused them to act better or worse. I absolutely think a Nazi killing a Jew is worse than a soldier saving a Jew. Neither of these events are meaningless. Every actions has a reaction. Hearing the first, I scowl. Hearing the second, I smile.

I think the world is deterministic, but the thing is that I can be one of the factors that help determine my future. If I don‚Äôt put effort into doing my part to make the world better, then the world will surely be worse than if I had. Causes have direct and traceable effects. I can be a cause that either affects the world for better or for worse, and it‚Äôs up to the molecular activity that makes up my thoughts to determine which. (I‚Äôm shooting for the former). 

I hope this provides a more hopeful alternative to your interpretation of determinism as a ‚Äú...viewpoint [you] loathe so much‚Äù. I also hope you have a great day.

replies.author: @tawdryhepburn4686
replies.text:
@juliadonati8245 thanks! Appreciate you reading my words and agreeing with my interpretation. Vonnegut was like a father to me in some ways. His books taught me about morality, humility, and storytelling writ large. That last one is especially important as I am a writer by trade. And Vonnegut definitely set me down that path. 

Funny thing about the word Grok. I learned it as just a word. It was something my college girlfriend would say. She learned it from her father. It wasn‚Äôt until years later that I learned it was a reference to Stranger in a Strange Land. But that‚Äôs the sign of a good neologism. You can use the phrase independent of the original context. As lovely and detailed as the Nadsat is, no word of phrase from that lexicon can hold up to the sheer utility of ‚ÄúGrok.‚Äù

replies.author: @tawdryhepburn4686
replies.text: @juliadonati8245 and I must say, your words are thought provoking. Determinism need not be depressing because _you_can be someone else‚Äôs determining factor. I never looked at it from that perspective. Sure, you still have the infinite regression, but I kinda feel like your point about the world surely being worse for the lack of your efforts counterbalances it effectively.

replies.author: @fluffymccuddlebuttons8501
replies.text:
Slaughterhouse 5 is a pretty obvious metaphor for what we would now call PTSD.

You can read it literally as a silly science fiction story, but there's a very obvious subtext to a lot of what is going on. Being forced to relive your own experiences while being powerless to change them, being alienated from your own life and feeling like you're not really in control, trying to rationalize what has happened by adopting a philosophy of indifference and retreating into fantasy in order to avoid reality are all things that might happen to people with PTSD.

It might seem weird to combine accounts of your real war experiences with goofy sci-fi shit, but that's kind of the point. Some things need to be wrapped in absurdity because otherwise they're too painful to deal with.

replies.author: @Jim_Ewing
replies.text: @SomePotato I didn't say they are my numbers. I've been studying military history for more than forty years. 100,000 is a very reasonable estimate. 35,000 bodies were recovered, but obviously they couldn't recover remains that were totally incinerated, and they also didn't recover remains that were trapped under rubble. Like I said, the population just a few years after the war was at least down by 100,000. What I am suggesting is that someone try to model the bombing attack, which took place over about three days, with hundreds of tons of bombs dropped. It was the first attack using more than 1,000 heavy bombers, and they deliberately came back the next day when rescue operations were underway. In case you didn't know, Germany is still occupied until 2099. They aren't even in charge of their own country. The victors are still in charge, so obviously they might have an agenda to downplay the losses.

replies.text: What is true is that Vonnegut was a POW in Germany when the firebombing occurred and this was clearly while WW2 in Germany was still going on -- well before May 7, 1945. It is interesting that KV mentions Irving's book decades before DI became known for Holocaust denial and racism. Importantly, I do not think Irving states that the bombing occurred after Germany's surrender. But it is also possible that Dresden was chosen to demoralize civilians -- that it was not primarily to interfere, for example, with production of planes or ammunition. Still, anything that happens during total war that helps hasten surrender could be considered valid strategically. Ethan is kind of a dope for not bothering to do some basic research: even if Wikipedia is not always accurate, that the article on Dresden's firebombing states that it occurred in February of 1945 ought to at least make him look at other sources.

replies.author: @pauligrossinoz
replies.text:
ArchNME - I wasn't _necessary_ to win the war, *but it definitely shortened the war* - thus saving the lives of Allied soldiers and also some Jews in concentration camps.

At the time of the bombing the Germans were withdrawing troops from the West to try to counter the Red Army in the East, which was within only 70km of Berlin. The troops and their equipment had to move through the central switchpoints at Dresden via the railroad, and the destruction of those central rail points was an excellent tactical move by Britain and the US in support of the Red Army's immediate objective: Berlin.

The inability of Hitler to effectively counter the Red Army at his door directly lead to their quick success and the end of the war. 

The deaths of less than 25,000 civilians was an ugly reality, but the destruction was the correct tactic at that time to end the war faster.

replies.author: @pauligrossinoz
replies.text:
ArchNME - no.

Just the previous week the Allies had concluded an agreement in the Crimea - the famous *Yalta conference* - where the post-war carve up of Germany was agreed to,  concluded _before_ Dresden was bombed.

The whole point of Yalta was to promote both strategic and tactical cooperation among the allies to shorten the war, avoiding exactly those kind of delaying tactics by any of the Allies that might slow down their inexorable progress. 

The bombing of Dresden was an interdiction tactic by the British and US with the explicit aim of supporting the Red Army's progress toward Berlin and hasten the Nazi collapse. The inability of Nazi troops to move through our even billet in Dresden was the primary aim of those bombing raids on Dresden.

The troops stationed there were destroyed, the blockbuster bombs put the railroad out of commission, and the firebombs destroyed any chance of Nazi troops getting respite as they rushed to meet the Red Army, which was fighting only 70km away from Berlin.

The Red Army was then able to consolidate its gains at a position only 60km from Berlin, virtually unopposed,  building their strength to 2.5 million soldiers over the next two months.

Berlin was then crushed by the Red Army in a week, ending the war by easily overwhelming the 750,000 defenders.

The tactical actions after the Yalta conference, including the firebombing of Dresden, left the Nazis scattered, demoralized and completely unable to counter the Red Army's progress to Berlin - thus ending the war as quickly as possible. 

The ugly aspect of the raids was the deliberate targeting of civilian areas to prevent any possibility of the Nazi troops rushing to Berlin getting any respite in Dresden, causing the deaths of more than 20,000 civilians. 

*But it is without any doubt that the sooner the end of the war, the greater the number of lives saved in the Nazi concentration camps.*

And, of course, the quicker the Red Army destroyed Berlin, the fewer British and US lives would be lost too.

replies.author: @pauligrossinoz
replies.text:
i minabrons - _as I had already explained,_ the *Yalta conference* was just concluded the previous week, and the Allies had agreed on the carve-up of post war Germany. There was no 'race to Berlin' after that. 

The Nazis were finished, it was only a question of how long it would take to destroy them, and the Red Army was only 70km from Berlin after the Yalta conference. 

The destruction of Dresden denied the Nazis any quick way to counter the impeding attack on Berlin by interdicting internal Nazi troop movements, and preventing them from getting any respite in the city.

The following two months the Red Army built its strength at the 60km mark outside Berlin virtually without Nazi opposition, because of the destruction of Dresden.

When their numbers had reached 2.5 million soldiers, plus a massive number of tanks and artillery, the Red Army attacked Berlin and crushed it in a week.

The attack on Dresden was a tactical interdiction strike by the British and US with the express purpose of supporting the Red Army's approach to Berlin. It worked and shortened the war.

In it, Vonnegut states how it happened on February 13th, 1945, and tha they were in the meatlocker for about 14 hours because they had to wait for the firestorm outside to die down, not days. He also describes how the civilians in Dresden were digging anti-tank trenches in the weeks after the bombing, preparing for the Soviet advance. However, the number of deaths described in his book has been questioned. But considering the fact that he himself was there collecting the bodies for days, it‚Äôs understandable that he would have had a high estimate of the death toll.

YJ C Thats a big line of bullshit, and isn‚Äôt backed by the historical record. Many ranking officers involved in the Pacific campaign advised against the bombings, stating that the bloated estimations of damage and death without their use didn‚Äôt hold water, and the declassified records show that the US was aware that Japan was in talks of negotiating a surrender with the Soviet Union(in the event that the USSR broke it‚Äôs stance of neutrality with Japan) long before the nukes were dropped. It was the day after Russia declared war that Japan surrendered. The US went ahead and dropped the bombs anyway, because they stood to gain a lot of clout on the world stage by doing so, and a few hundred thousand foreign civilian lives is a small price to pay for such a huge political advantage.

In fact, the US didn‚Äôt even stop with the nukes, on the day that Japan had surrendered, (but before the surrender had been publicly announced) the US firebombed Japanese cities with nearly 1000 B-29 bombers, along with the bombs, they dropped propaganda leaflets with the writing: ‚ÄúJapan surrenders.‚Äù These raids were carried out on civilian populations with the knowledge that the war was already over. If the US was so concerned with Japanese lives, How do you explain these tactics, or the fact that they are conveniently unmentioned in US history books.

replies.author: @br3669
replies.text: @6Shooter28 I couldn't find a corroborating source for this particular quote either, but what I could find was a historian's blog post who found a very similar one by a young woman by the name Eva Benda, who said in principle the same "From our windows we watched Dresden burning only a short distance away. For us it was an exhilarating sight. The whole horizon was aflame, and our dormitory was lit as if by daylight, except the light was red. We knew that the Allies had bombed Dresden. We stood at the windows all night, delighting in the spectacle. To us it was proof that the end of the war and liberation could not be far off." (Eva Benda: From Prague to Theresienstadt and Back, in: Martin Ira Glass, Robert Krell (Hrsg.): And Life is Changed Forever. Holocaust Childhoods Remembered. Detroit 2006, pp. 251-276, here: p. 264.) Eva Benda was in Oederan (ca 30 miles form Dresden) at the time, not in Theresienstadt but she had been brought to Oederan from Theresienstadt a few months earlier. The statement in the video could originate with Eva Benda's in however many rounds of slight misquoting.

@SakushaDurante-q8f the necessity of any target in war is always debatable, there won't be a definite answer, so saying it was only revenge fantasy is too simple. one might argue, that it was so late in the war, that Nazi-Germany woul've lost soon anyways. Another point is the method of carpet bombing. Why didn't the allies use more precision bombing runs to precisely destroy military, industry and infrastructure instead of bombing civilians.

But your challenge doesn't prove a point. You don't need proof of a soldier or SS dying in Dresden because of all the terrible things that were going on:
Churchill already had declared the war against civilians as necessary, so bombing civs "was fine" for the allies (especially since it was in no way worse than what the Nazis did to other civilians), while the Nazi-Volkssturm ordered everyone to defend the Vaterland, effectively turning every German into a "soldier" at least from the perspective of the f√ºhrerbunker. So is that proof of soldiers dying there? 

So many germans surrendered at the sight of the enemy at the late war period, because they knew it was over. Sadly you cannot surrender during a bombing run or while a V2 rocket lands on your head. War is shit and war against civilian is even shittier

Edit:
The point is: there is a way to argue against the bombing of civilians (in general) and especially in Dresden. But none of those should be used to defend a Nazi-Ideology or to rewrite history. We should take it as what it is. It is an atrocity of war. Calling those who committed atrocities heroes is wrong, but saying the victims were free of any guilt is also wrong.

replies.author: @brucetucker4847
replies.text: @darth0tator "Why didn't the allies use more precision bombing runs to precisely destroy military, industry and infrastructure instead of bombing civilians." The Americans tried. It didn't work very well for a number of reasons: unguided bombs are inherently inaccurate, especially from the high altitudes at which they had to fly to avoid being annihilated by the very heavy and effective German flak, skilled bombardiers were hard to train, it only worked when the weather was perfect, and above all losses in daylight raids were horrific until the last year or so of the war when the Luftwaffe was hamstrung by lack of fuel and Allied long-range escorts were able to gain air superiority over Germany.

replies.text: @mito88 Strategic bombing wasn't always terror bombing, but it could be. Harris' area bombing was, but, for instance, the very effective Allied attack on the French rail network leading up to D-Day certainly wasn't meant to inflict terror on the French population. Likewise the two Ploesti raids, the Schweinfurt ball bearing factory raids, and many others were meant to destroy plants producing vital war materials, not randomly kill civilians.

replies.text:
@bblvrable Do you even know how the bombing of Dresden was carried out? Do you know what a fire storm is and how it kills, what it leaves and doesn't leave behind? Clue: the Frauenkirche - the main Protestant Church and biggest attraction in the city's old town, succumbed and was destroyed not by thr bombs falling and hitting it (its walls were thick enough to endure even direct hits during both days of the air raid) it was the heat reaching 1,830¬∞F in that part of the city caused by the fire storm that engulfed much of the city centre which literally turned its pillars and foundation into red-hot explosive matter and its walls into molten stuff. 
For what it's worth, the accounts of survivors witnessing untold numbers of people being sucked in by the fire storm and others glued to the pavement while burning are numerous. As per the Red Cross the amount of people living in Dresden could have easily been set to near one million at the time of the bombings  as the city had been used as a kind of city hospital and evacuation muster station for hundreds of thousands of German  refugees from Silesia and Posen (both regions now in Poland). Dresden had around 600 000 native inhabitants.

replies.author: @Uriel238
replies.text:
@seamusoneill9681 considering the degree of controversy around the subject, it would be folly to accept such an instance as fact without some evidence. As you pointed out the NYT hailed his suggestions, and I'm pretty sure that every issue in 1940 has been archived, so if it is true, the fruit of your research is assured. I'd certainly be interested to know what editorialist decided Kaufman was worth the time of day.

Kaufman was known as a radicalist _at the time._ To be fair there were a lot of radicals who wanted to do radical things, including, for instance, the Bushes (the family from which we've had two Presidents of the United States) who were so enamored of fascism they wanted to install it right here in the US. A plot for a quiet coup was already in place, but it was stopped by Marine Corps general named Smedley. (Yes, really.)

But one guy is not a movement, as demonstrated every single day online by radicals of every wash caught saying stupid things and getting their mug posted on the internet. A movement involves _people_ at very least by the hundreds. Otherwise, it's more of a congregation or a support group.

The Kaufmanists did not make much of a mark in history.

There's also that matter that scientific racism, prenology, eugenics and racial purity were the popular notions world wide. (And yes, applying selective breeding to a group does allow one to favor traits, but who decides what traits are favorable?)

Also it's probably a good idea not to assume that _any_ identity group (Jews, Conservatives, Feminists, Christians, Communists, whatever) universally share _any_ given ideological notion, even when it might seem axiomatic to that group. If there's more than a thousand of them, you'll always be able to find someone who disagrees.

And you'll always be able to find radicals and stupid people who say extreme or stupid at which you can point to besmirch a group as Goebbels did Kaufman. It's a popular pastime, but it's a dishonest argument.

author: @seasidescott
text:
Now I know where some friends were getting their "facts". They've been interjecting historical and other out-of-character information into discussions and at first I wondered about their newfound interest in studying these issues. They seemed quite satisfied with themselves "knowing" things usually only expected of those of us who read. I did point out some of their misinformation and referenced Wikipedia which they then said was bullshit until I showed them how to use the footnotes to find the sources of information...and that degraded into "can't trust things on the internet"... which is exactly where they got the information they trusted without looking at their sources. 
The truly disturbing part is that they felt so smug, so powerful, being able to quote something, as if they'd found the magic shortcut to being as smart as anyone else. One actually said "now I know as much as you" even after his info was disproved. Wow. That alt-crap is a powerful drug. I actually felt sorry for him and pulled back a bit because obviously he was experiencing a new source of self-worth that was so intertwined with his "facts" that disputing them would be attacking his self-worth. 
We don't talk so much lately.

replies.author: @williamchamberlain2263
replies.text: I'd say that Bomber Command were too wedded to early 1930s technical capabilities - that they had too low an opinion of the abilities of their aircrews in hitting point targets if they operated in small numbers,  underestimated how fast bombers could be, and didn't allocate enough material away from bomber production to long-range twin-engine fighter escorts.   That's hindsight and not issues easy to change once training and production lines are running, but it could have been done.

replies.author: @Pretermit_Sound
replies.text:
@williamchamberlain2263they also put too much faith in the new technology of the time. A good example of this is the Norden Bomb Sight. It was an incredibly complex analog computer that allowed the bomber crew to accurately calculate the trajectory the bomb needed to take in order to hit their targets accurately enough to be effective. They were incredibly advanced for the time, and were so precise, and were capable of such a high level of accuracy that they were actually classified top secret until after the war. 
 The problem was, their capabilities, and operating procedures were all based on testing conducted in controlled, laboratory conditions, and it was discovered after the war that the Norden Sights had been rendered all but useless when they were used in real world combat conditions that were experienced on the bombing missions. They had been essentially dropping their bombs blind, not realizing they had no idea where they would land. This resulted in countless unnecessary, and preventable civilian casualties. üòû

text: One thing a lot of people seem to be forgetting is that WWII followed a doctrine known as "total war." What this means is that a nation's entire industrial output, both military and civilian, is focused on the war effort. As a result, both military and civilian infrastructure were considered legitimate targets. Dresden was no different.

author: @QuannanHade
text:
My Grandfather was one of the refugees escaping the Red Army - a German national from what is now just over the border in Poland. His story is that he and his family were instructed that they couldn't camp in the city itself, and to move along. It was this instruction that he attributes to his survival - as "My brother and I woke up to fireworks, and the city was gone in the morning."

Unfortunately for my Great-grandmother, Dresden also held the only surviving copy of her marriage certificate, which meant she couldn't enter East Germany after the war to visit her family alongside my Great-grandfather.

author: @DrCruel
text:
"Large variations in the claimed death toll have fuelled the controversy. In March 1945, the German government ordered its press to publish a falsified casualty figure of 200,000 for the Dresden raids, and death toll estimates as high as 500,000 have been given. The city authorities at the time estimated up to 25,000 victims, a figure that subsequent investigations supported, including a 2010 study commissioned by the city council."
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombing_of_Dresden_in_World_War_II

The problem with determining the exact death toll is due to the accumulation of refugees in the city at the time.

About Dresden:
Frankly, I don‚Äôt fucking get why this is such a big sticking point. The bombing of Cologne a far more culturally significant and industrially significant city killed 40000, however the fights over what became the cities in East Germany like Berlin fought between the advancing Red Army and the Germans (including drafted women children and old folk) killed far more people. In fact if you do even an ounce of research you would see that the bombigns were asked for by Stalin to prevent another Battle of Budapest where the Soviets had to fight brutal house by house urban combat against the Germans to liberate the city. This killed many more civilians and troops then the bombing of Dresden as there is no Battle of Dresden, The Soviets took it with minimal resistance in a few days,

I find it funny that these neo-Nazis think that this is so bad because either way, long protracted battle or massive bombing campaign.  It‚Äôs still a shit load of people dying for no reason, war bad and there is no good war or good way to conduct a war, there is only the least worst way which was evaluated by the allies as the way to get the war over with with as little time and friendly casualties as possible.

@nicobruin8618 that's simplistic, the point is the allies enthusiastically engaged in bombing civilian population centres, in precisely the same way and for the same purpose as the nazis. You could argue that they initiated it back in 1940, or that it was necessary to overthrow a horrific regime as quickly as possible. 

However when you engage in the same tactics as literally the most horrific dictatorship the world has ever known, then it is far more difficult to paint yourselves as beacons of virtue (which the Western allies still do to this day, on the basis of defeating nazi Germany). Its legitimate to recognise this, without having any sympathies to the nazis. 

Three arrows makes a good argument in the video, and there are clearly dangers to having idiots misrepresent what happened, whether that be due to ignorance or for propaganda purposes. But there is also the danger of failing to acknowledge the horrors that the allies unleashed during ww2. If you ignore these facts, or are willing to downplay/justify horrific acts that your side commits, even if it is in the name of a righteous cause, then that that is worrying.

I would argue western powers, particularly the UK and USA have done this ever since 1945. I would also argue that this mindset has made these 2 countries far less wary about waging war and has contributed to recent foreign policy disasters such as Iraq.

author: @AnnaNym-h5k
text:
To be entirely fair, accurate bombing of specific targets was incredibly difficult at the time. Even in daylight, US bombers could only hope to get 20% of their bombs within 300m of the target. British bombers, at least after the US entered the war, almost exclusively flew at night, and the H2S radar (which was developed to help identify targets) could really only be used to identify a city, not to pinpoint a specific target within it. 

Essentially, carpet bombing was a necessity driven by technological limitations. Precision bombing was only viable under certain conditions that simply did not exist over most of German territory, and especially not over Dresden.

Flying strategic bomber raids over the length of WW2 was very dangerous and bomber crews experienced the highest loss rates of any service arms on the Allied side. As for Churchill, all national leaders in WW2 had a lot of blood on their hands, but like I said at the start, total war is total hell.

author: @johnscurr2501
text:
A good, non-hysteria induced summary. Thank you. I've been to Dresden several times and it still is a beautiful city, one can only imagine what it must have been before February '45 (as you correctly point out months before the war ground to a halt) Much has been written concerning the horror of that night and the following day and much of it has been total hogwash. The best account I've read (note I am not saying there were not inaccuracies - there may be but for sure there are fewer than in anything else i've read) is Dresden by Frederick Taylor. I had the pleasure of spending some time with a survivor on one of my trips who showed me round the Altstadt and the Nuestadt. As a  young boy his mother took firstly him out to the street to take charge of the family as she found them and brought them out then went back to the cellar which was filling with water to get others from the family. He never saw her, his siblings or others from his family sheltering the cellars again.
I can't even begin to imagine that scenario but he lived it. Now I am no apologist for whatever it took to bring the Nazis to their knees and I replied, somewhat crassly really because what can one say to somebody who has that horror in his personal history, that it was a shame that which fell upon Dresden and his family. He stopped me with the following, "Hey it was Germany which started that whole business, those who brought it to an end cannot be blamed for it just because they ended it so completely, Germans caused this to happen nobody else". Though at one level I could not argue the logic of that it did not alter the simple fact that it was a shame. Not a thing to be ashamed of as total war means total war but it was something to regret both his personal loss and the loss of such beauty to a world quite short of beauty at the time its destruction. Until fate decreed otherwise I had a plan of retiring to Meissen and even purchased property, so have a deep feeling for the area and many lovely people who I met there. I will return for sure before it's my time to jump off this mortal coil. 
However I will never disparage Bomber Harris or the horror of what he was tasked to do.  The Russians in particular needed those marshalling yards at the train station ruined as any resupply/reinforcement of the German Army still fighting them would come through there. Although bombing accuracy had improved in the years from the early bombings of Germany it could in no way ever be termed precision bombing. Bomber Harris and his crews just did what they were tasked to do which was destroy German cities - not pretty, not particularly moral, not particularly ethical but it was total war and nobody should point the finger at anyone simply because they fought that total war more totally in the long run than their opponents. Nobody forced Germany into a warlike tour of Europe in 1939. Germany and the German populace made that decision, nobody else. Do not attack a dog and then act surprised when that dog bites back! 
I lived in Germany for a total of eight wonderful years, 2 of them in Berlin itself and I see Germany as my second home in particular I love the whole area of Sachsen and whilst I view the long since cleared up destruction as regrettable brought about by human folly I will never feel the need to apologize for my forefathers having brought the horror of the Nazi era to a halt by any and all means open to them. If I were German I would probably view it in much the same way. It seems there are some amongst the current generation of Germans who view it differently and would be happy to resurrect the whole notion once more. We can only hope the sane majority prevail but we have to keep an eye on the simple fact the sane majority stood by and allowed Adolf Hitler and his psychopaths to hoodwink and silence them in equal measure and took them down a one way road to the horror and destruction brought to them which they had wished to inflict on others. Don't sleep walk into that abyss again please Germany, you should be admired for your positive traits and natural beauty not the aberrations you cause.

"It seems to me that the moment has come when the question of bombing of German cities simply for the sake of increasing the terror, though under other pretexts, should be reviewed. Otherwise we shall come into control of an utterly ruined land ... The destruction of Dresden remains a serious query against the conduct of Allied bombing. I am of the opinion that military objectives must henceforward be more strictly studied in our own interests than that of the enemy.


The Foreign Secretary has spoken to me on this subject, and I feel the need for more precise concentration upon military objectives such as oil and communications behind the immediate battle-zone, rather than on mere acts of terror and wanton destruction, however impressive."


Winston Churchill.

author: @Zones33
text:
The suburbs of Dresden where were the majority of the industry was, yet they focused solely on the urban area itself. It's pretty clear what their intentions were due to the ferocity of non-stop bombing for 3 days. 1. The hope was the decrease German citizen morale, which had the complete opposite affect. This is particularly tone deaf given that the people in London experienced the same solidarity after the battle of Britain. 2. The western allies did not want the soviets to establish any more presence in the south of Germany according to Richard Overy. So to try and say it was morally ambiguous is a pretty sleazy statement given that 25k people still died in 3 days. Saying bullshit like "you reap what you sow" or any other type of nonsense doesn't change that.

Also lol @ quick war is a humane one. Can't really say that for a 6 hour nuclear war can we?

replies.author: @harmdallmeyer6449
replies.text:
Dresden was still the major transport hub to Support the eastern front. It had one of the largest still intact Railway Networks, and housed Up to 20.000 troops a day in their way eastward.

Also, the Soviets asked for more German Transportaktion Hubs to be destroyed in the Yalta Conference

author: @yingyang1008
text:
"We killed altogether about 400,000 Germans,* one third of them in the two fire storms in Hamburg and Dresden. The Dresden fire storm was the worst. But from our point of view it was only a fluke. We attacked Berlin sixteen times with the same kind of force that attacked Dresden once. We were trying every time to raise a fire storm. There was nothing special about Dresden except that for once everything worked as we intended. It was like a hole in one in a game of golf.‚Ä† Unfortunately, Dresden had little military importance, and anyway the slaughter came too late to have any serious effect on the war.

Kurt Vonnegut wrote a book called Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade about the Dresden raid. For many years I had intended to write a book on the bombing. Now I do not need to write it, because Vonnegut has written it much better than I could. He was in Dresden at the time and saw what happened. His book is not only good literature. It is also truthful."

Freeman Dyson, British Bomber Command

author: @danzervos7606
text:
Dresden was a major supplier of optics for Germany's guns (cannons, used for example in their tanks).  The Western Allies were being pressured by Russia to do something to reduce the German forces fighting their forces.  Dresden was a major supply junction to the East.  

Clearly terror (area) bombing did not cause the German people to rise up against their leadership as was hoped.   It didn't work in Japan either.   However it did weaken Germany and Japan ability to continue the battle.   At the very least it tied up tens of thousand of Axis soldiers manning AA guns and fighters.
